2,Email,,,,2,What is an email alias and how do I add one to HubSpot?,,,,,"

Think of an alias as a ""nickname"" for your main email. The alias will share contacts, the inbox for incoming mail, and account settings with the primary inbox. The difference is that an alias has a different name than your primary email address. For example, if firstname@hubspot.com is my primary address. I could add sales@hubspot.com to my account as an alias, so I can send to contacts from the ""sales@"" address.
There are two main ways to add an email alias:
1) Add the alias via Profile and Preferences in the ""Security"" section.
2) Add the alias directly from your email client. Please note that we will only auto-detect aliases that are added in Gmail in HubSpot-- this doesn't happen for other email providers at this time.

What is it?

This update allows users to send emails that are part of a sequence at whatever time the recipient is most likely to engage.

Why does it matter?

Send time recommendations uses the data we’ve collected about a prospect or customer to send them an email at the time they’re most likely to engage. With the latest update, Sales and Service Hub users can leverage Sequences to optimize efficiency and still take advantage of the intelligence that send time recommendations provide.

How does it work?

Users will be able to select the time that their emails are sent, select a time range during which their emails will be sent, or opt to send follow-ups at the recommended send times:

Who gets it?

This feature is in beta, currently out to 10% of portals (who have Sales Hub Professional).

Source: Prod Notifications

Send time recommendations in sequences take into account a couple of things:

- previous email history and interactions (not specific to sequences)

- publicly available contact demographics

Historical sends and opens are relative to the user-contact pair… so if the same person is a contact in two different portals, the history is not shared.

Source: Scott Judson, the PM

What is it?

The latest update brings more flexibility to the meeting booking experience. Now, users have the option to set a custom date range for when meetings can be booked:

Why does it matter?

Have you ever been to a conference or tradeshow? It’s the perfect time to network and book meetings with prospective customers, vendors, or partners. The problem is that your availability during the event is typically much different than your normal availability. This update makes it possible for users to configure their meetings links for specific events or windows of time.

How does it work?

Under Advanced Settings, click the “When a meeting can be scheduled” dropdown menu and select “Custom date range”. Click the date picker fields and set your time range. Please note that a custom date range cannot be longer than 10 weeks.
Once a date range has expired, users may go back and update the dates.

13,Quotes,,,,1,"Effective 9/5/18, Quotas will no longer be included for free in HubSpot CRM",,,,,"

What is it?

Effective 9/5, quotas will be removed from HubSpot Free.*

The quotas feature will continue to be available to users with a paid seat of Sales Hub or Service Hub, but will be renamed “Goals” to be more broadly applicable across hubs.

*Existing free users will not lose access to quotas. They will be grandparented in and will retain access to the functionality that they are familiar with today.

Why does it matter?

“Quota” is a term that has traditionally been associated with sales, but the idea of giving an individual a goal and helping them track toward that goal extends outside the realm of sales. In fact, these goals can come in all shapes and sizes: calls made, meetings booked, revenue won, tickets closed… the list goes on.

Changing the “quotas” feature to “goals” allows us to provide both sales and services teams a consistent (and flexible) user interface to build, track, and report on goals.

INTERNAL NOTE:

We’ve made the call to remove “quotas” (and “goals”) from HubSpot free because doing so aligns with this idea that quota-carrying front-line reps should have a paid seat to get the most value out of HubSpot.

How’s it going to work?

Because existing free users will be grandparented in and will retain access to the quotas functionality that they are familiar with, there’s a little bit of complexity around who gets what. Let'
column2:
s break it down:

  • “Legacy quotas” refers to the existing quotas tool. It’s monthly, fixed quotas per individual.

  • “Basic goals” refers to monthly, fixed quotas. It’s pretty much the same functionality as “legacy quotas”. After 9/5, basic goals will be available to Sales Hub Starter or Sales Hub Professional users.

  • “Advanced goals” refers to historical goals (quota ramps), multiple types of goals, and varying frequencies (monthly, quarterly, annually). After 9/5, advanced goals will be available to Sales Hub Enterprise or Service Hub Enterprise users -- but in slightly different flavors (more info below).

...So, who gets what?

All users on all portals created prior to 9/5 will have access to legacy quotas.

Effective 9/5, any net-new Sales Hub Starter or Sales Hub Professional portals will get access to basic goals.

Effective 9/5, any net-new Sales Hub Enterprise or Service Hub Enterprise users will get access to advanced goals.

For Sales Hub Enterprise, Managers can assign one of four types of Goals: Revenue per rep, Meetings per rep, Calls per rep, Deals created per rep. Goals can be set on a weekly, monthly, quarterly, or annual basis, and goals for a given time period will be stored historically.

For Service Hub Enterprise, Managers can assign one of four types of Goals: Tickets closed by agent, Average Resolution Time by agent, Average Response Time by agent, CES by agent. Goals can be set on a weekly, monthly, quarterly, or annual basis, and goals for a given time period will be stored historically.

Effective 9/5, any net-new free portals will NOT have access to user-based goals or quotas. These portals WILL be able to add company-level goals to individual dashboard reports.

IMPORTANT NOTES:

  1. In the event of an upgrade to Enterprise, a grandfathered portal would need to add all users who should have quotas assigned as paid users in the portal in order to assign them advanced goals. If that was followed by a downgrade to Professional or lower, the grandfathered portal would then go back to Basic Goals.

  1. If a portal has both Sales and Service Enterprise, users can only be assigned Goal types for the subscription that they have. Example: Service Enterprise user can get Ticket Goal assigned, but not a Revenue goal assigned.

Source: Product Notifications
